ContentClassification.TableDescription: 1952 Graduated Rates of Disablement - Benefit 5, Time Period: 2. Elimination Period: 360 days. Minimum Age: 10. Maximum Age: 59
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: The Committee on Disability and Double Indemnity presented in 1952 the results of an intercompany study of the experience of eleven companies under certain ordinary disability benefits between 1930 and 1950 anniversaries. (“Experience Under Certain Ordinary Disability Benefits Between the 1930 and 1950 Anniversaries”, Reports of the Society of Actuaries (1952)). Benefit 5 represents 6-month waiting period clause, providing waiver of premiums only; issued only when applied for, subject to a specific extra premium. Methodology: The rates of disablement were derived as the ratio of the amount of admissions to disability benefit with date of disablement in a particular policy year to the mean in force of active lives over such policy year, approximated in most cases as the December 31st valuation in force. While Period 2 rates of disablement (between 1935 and 1939 anniversaries) are not exactly midway between those for Period 1 (1930-1935) which are high, and Period 4 (1946--1950) which are low, they are believed to represent a reasonable approach to the problem of attempting to use what might be considered an average or "long-term" level of disability rates. The individual age disablement rates for Period 2 were graduated by the Whittaker-Henderson "A" formula minimizing third differences, with a* = 4. At the youngest ages, rates based on exposures of less than $5 million of life insurance at a single age were excluded from the graduation. At the youngest ages, rates based on exposures of less than $5 million of life insurance at a single age were excluded from the graduation. The Period 2 graduated rates of disablement for each of the Benefits 1 to 5, inclusive, were shown in the 1952 Disability Report for attained ages 18 to 59 inclusive. However, in the interest of making monetary values as complete as possible without serious inaccuracy, it was decided to extend the rates of disablement for Benefit 5 down to age 5 as Benefit 5 is currently being issued by various companies below age 15, it was thought advisable to adopt rates of disablement at least down to age 10 . For attained age 17, under Benefit 5, the Committee actually obtained a graduated rate but the rate was not published. As the rates of disablementat the young ages are relatively small so that any changes in these rates would have only a minor effect on the net premiums, it was considered reasonable to use the rate of disablement for age 17 at attained ages 10 to 17 inclusive under Benefit 5.
